title.narrative: UNIDO ZAMITA vocational training Volvo phase 2 PPDP
UNIDO ZAMITA yrkesutbildning Volvo fas 2 PPDP

description.narrative:
Andelen unga av totala befolkningen i Zambia är bland den högsta i världen och för den växande unga befolkningen är sysselsättningsmöjligheterna få. Projektet syftar till att adressera bristen på produktiv sysselsättning för zambiska ungdomar, inom sektorerna transport, gruvnäring, konstruktion, jordbruk och skogsbruk. Målet att öka sysselsättningsmöjligheterna för unga uppnås genom att utveckla en efterfrågad och modern läroplan för mekaniker, erbjuda relevant och efterfrågad yrkesutbildning till elever (med fokus på ungdomar från fattiga förhållanden) samt att stärka kapaciteten hos yrkesutbildningscenter i Zambia.
Projektet utgör en fas två av den insats som inleddes 2015. Målet då var att etablera en modern akademi, i samarbete med Volvo-gruppen, som kunde förse främst gruvindustrin med relevanta utbildningsprogram och adekvat utbildade elever. Projektets mål uppnåddes då ca 670 studenter har utbildats, en ny nationell läroplan för Heavy Equipment Repair (HER) utvecklats och kapaciteten att leverera utbildningar i enlighet med denna har ökats.
Utifrån lärdomarna från första fasen har parterna kommit överens om att fortsätta samarbetet, men nu fokusera mer på transportsektorn då behovet där är stort och antalet arbetstillfällen fler än i själva gruvsektorn. Stödet till HER kommer dock att fortsätta i någon mån och utbildningen kommer att utformas för att passa även andra viktiga sektorer.
Projektet genomförs, liksom i första fasen, som ett samarbete mellan privat och offentlig sektor, i ett sk Public Private Development Partnership. Styrkan i partnerskapet mellan privat och offentlig sektor ligger främst i möjligheten att översätta industrins behov av utbildad arbetskraft till nya läroplaner, läromedel, lärarutbildning, relevant praktiktjänstgöring etc. och därigenom skapa en utbildning som motsvarar arbetsmarknadens behov och på så vis öka elevernas sysselsättningsmöjligheter.
Sida/ambassaden kommer att bidra med 12 MSEK och Volvo med 10 MSEK, vilket kan jämföras med tidigare fas då Sida bidrog med 12,9 MSEK och Volvo med drygt 15 MSEK. Projektet genomförs under tiden oktober 2019-december 2022.
UNIDO, FN:s organ för industriell utveckling, kommer att leda projektets genomförande, liksom tidigare fas av projektet. Projektet genomförs på den tekniska yrkesskolan NORTEC i Ndola och stöttas av ministeriet för högre utbildning och TEVETA, det nationella organet för yrkesutbildning. Alla parter bidrar på olika sätt till projektet.

The proportion of young people of the total population in Zambia is among the highest in the world and there are very few employment opportunities for the growing young population. This project aims to addressing the lack of productive employment for Zambian youth, in the transport, mining, construction, agriculture and forestry sectors. The goal of increasing employment opportunities for young people is achieved by developing modern curriculum for mechanics, in line with the needs of the private sector, offer relevant and demanded vocational training to students (focusing on disadvantaged and resource-poor youth) and strengthening the capacity of vocational training centers in Zambia.
The project is a phase two of a project that started in 2015. The goal was to establish a modern academy in collaboration with the Volvo Group, which could be offering the mining industry relevant vocational education programs and adequately educated students. The goal of the project was achieved as approximately 670 students were trained, a new national curriculum for Heavy Equipment Repair (HER) developed and capacities to deliver training in line with this curriculum were increased.
Based on lessons learned from the first phase, the parties have agreed to continue the cooperation, but now focus more on the transport sector as there is a great need and the number of jobs available are more than those in the mining sector itself. Support to HER will however continue to a smaller extent and the training will be designed to suit also other important sectors.
The project is implemented, as in the first phase, as a collaboration between the private and public sectors, in a so-called Public Private Development Partnership. The strength of partnerships between private and public sectors lies mainly in the possibilities of translating the industry need for skilled labor into modern curricula, teaching materials, teacher training, relevant internships, etc. and thereby creating an education that meets the needs of the labour market and thus increase the employment opportunities for students.
Sida / the Embassy will contribute with SEK 12 million and Volvo with SEK 10 million, which can be compared to the previous phase for which Sida contributed SEK 12.9 million and Volvo with a bit over SEK 15 million. The project will be implemented for the period October 2019 to December 2022.
UNIDO, the United Nations Industrial Development Agency, will lead the project implementation, as in the previous phase of the project. The project is being implemented at the NORTEC technical vocational school in Ndola and is supported by the Ministry of Higher Education and TEVETA, the national vocational training body. All parties support the project in different ways.

The overall objective of the project is to enhance youth employability in the transport and heavy duty equipment sector in Zambia.
The outcome of the project is to provide effective and relevant industrial skills training to young Zambians; and help them transition into gainful employment by becoming more skilled, and therefore more employable.
Output 1: Gap between employers expectations and current educational standards for the transport and heavy equipment sector bridged through the development of a competency-based qualification framework and modern curriculum
Output 2: Regional centre of excellence created by improving NORTECs institutional capacity through the provision of modern equipment and Training of Trainers (ToT) as well as scaling up across Zambia through the provision of relevant equipment and technology transfer trainings
Output 3: Training and career services provided to 450 young Zambians, with a particular focus on female and disadvantaged students

description.narrative:
Covid-19 affected activities involving international travel and deliveries from Volvo and Government of Zambia (GRZ). Alternatives to international travel through in-country and digital platforms were used while the activities involving Volvo stalled for more than eight (8) months due to the plant closure in Sweden.
Communications with GRZ were intermittent due to the lockdowns and the election in August 2021. Since July 2021, Volvo has resumed its support to the project while the GRZ is expected to resume its support in full once the new government completes restructuring. The project management team channeled resources into the digitalization of Nortec education to support the students to continue studies remotely.
Outputs achieved include 11 staff development programs, refurbishment of 9 classrooms, 7 classrooms digitalized, and 6 in-house fabrication projects. In addition, 150 female and vulnerable bursary students from all across Zambia were admitted to NORTEC.
UNIDO is a strong partner in terms of reporting and communication. Monthly activity reports and regular social media communication are a complement to the annual progress reports. The quality of the reporting is high, providing both relevant details but also a clear sense of overall achievements.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
